common_error_warning_patterns.pattern: Temperature above threshold, cpu clock throttled
common_error_warning_patterns.advice: Test caused CPU temperature above critical threshold. Insufficient cooling?
The boot processor is not enumerated!

common_error_warning_patterns.pattern: Wrong _BBN value, reboot and use option 'pci=noacpi'
common_error_warning_patterns.advice: The BIOS has wrong _BBN value, which will make PCI root bridge have wrong bus number

common_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI.*apic on CPU.* stops in C2
common_error_warning_patterns.advice: The local apic timer incorrectly stops during C2 idle state.The ACPI specification forbids this and Linux needs the local APIC timer to work. The most likely cause of this is that the firmware uses a hardware C3 or C4 state that is mapped to the ACPI C2 state.
The kernel detected an irq storm. This is most probably an IRQ routing bug.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: BIOS has a garbled _PRT entry; source_name and source_index swapped.
The ACPI _PCT data is invalid.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Error.*ACPI path has too many parent prefixes
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: A path to an ACPI obejct has too many ^ parent prefixes and references passed the top of the root node. Please check AML for all ^ prefixed ACPI path names.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Error.*A valid RSDP was not found
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: An ACPI-compatible system must provide an RSDP (Root System Description Pointer in the system’s low address space. This structure’s only purpose is to provide the physical address of the RSDT and XSDT.
Attempted to release of a Mutex that was not previous acquired. This needs fixing as it could lead to race conditions when operating on a resource that needs to be proteced by a Mutex.
ACPI video driver has encountered a brightness level that is outside the expected range.

Section 6.2.10.2 of V4.0a of the ACPI specification states that the _OSC Method should be passed an 8 byte buffer of 2 x 32 DWORDs, however it appears that the method is possibly trying to access data outside this buffer. This is a bug in the _OSC method.
The field exceeds the allocated buffer size. This can lead to unexpected results when fetching data outside this region.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Error.*Illegal I/O port address/length above 64K
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: A port address or length has exceeded the maximum allowed 64K address limit. This will lead to unpredicable errors.
An ACPI Method has returned an unexpected and incorrect return type.
An ACPI Method has returned an Integer type when a Buffer, String or Package was expected.
An ACPI Method has returned an Device type when a Reference type was expected.
The ACPI Method did not return a value and was expected too. This is a bug and needs fixing.
A Method has returned a Package List that was larger than expected.

An illegal AML opcode has been found and is ignored. This indicates either badly compiled code or opcode corruption in the DSDT or SSDT tables or a bug in the ACPI execution engine. Recommend disassembing using iasl to find any offending code.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Warning.*Detected an unsupported executable opcode
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: An illegal AML opcode has been found and is ignored. This indicates either badly compiled code or opcode corruption in the DSDT or SSDT tables or a bug in the ACPI execution engine. Recommend disassembing using iasl to find any offending code.
The BIOS has found a BIOS32 Service Directory but the BIOS has returned error 0x80 on calling the service, which indicates that the requested service has not been implemented in the firmware.
The BIOS has found a BIOS32 Service Directory but the BIOS has returned an error on calling the service, which is unexpected and usually means the firmware is broken.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: PCI: Error.*when fetching IRQ routing table
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: The BIOS has been interrogated for the PCI IRQ routing table but the BIOS returned an error.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Error.*Denied AML access to port
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: AML code was accessing an I/O port that was banned from accesses. Ports 0x20-0x21 (PIC0), 0xa0-0xa1 (PIC1), 0x4d0-0x4d1 (ELCR) are always banned. For _OSI() greater or equal to 'Windows 2001' (Windows XP) ports 0x00-0x0f (DMA), 0x40-0x43 (PIT1), 0x48-0x4b (PIT2), 0x70-0x71 (RTC), 0x81-0x83 (DMA1), 0x87 (DMA1L), 0x89-0x8b (DMA2), 0x8f (DMA2L), 0x90-0x91 (ARBC), 0x93-0x94 (SETUP), 0x96-0x97 (POS), 0xc0-0xdf (ISA DMA) and 0xcf8-0xcff (PCI config) are banned.  Since the AML code has been banned from accessing these ports you will get undefined behaviour and the AML code should be fixed.
The ACPI Method was expected to return a value and did not.
The ACPI Method returned a table of the incorrect length. This can lead to unexepected results.
Method failed: ResourceSourceIndex is present but ResourceSource is not.
Method failed to allocate owner ID.

A Mutex acquire failed, which could possibly indicate that it was previously acquired and not released, or a race has occurred. Some AML code fails to miss Mutex acquire failures, so it is a good idea to verify all Mutex Acquires using the syntaxcheck test.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Error.*SMBus or IPMI write requires Buffer of
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: An incorrect SMBus or IPMI write buffer size was used.
The ACPI engine has failed to execute the _BCM Brightness Control Method.  This will result in possibly failing to set the display brightness level.
Executing the ACPI Method leaded in an execution failure. This needs investigating.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Warning.*Optional field.*has zero address or length
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: An ACPI table contains Generic Address Structure that has an address that is incorrectly set to zero, or a zero length. This needs to be fixed.

The FADT table contains a mismatch between the 32 bit pointer (DSDT) and 64 bit pointer (X_DSDT) pointer to the FACS table.  Section 5.2.9 of version 4.0a of the ACPI specification states that X_DSDT should be zero if DSDT is defined, or DSDT should be zero if X_DSDT is zero. With two different pointers defined, the kernel has to make a choice, and opts for the 32 bit pointer. Because these pointers are different, it suggests either one of them is incorrect, or different 32 bit and 64 bit DSDT tables are present in your system, which is NOT complaint with the ACPI specification.  The kernel has to make a choice and opts for the 32 bit DSDT.

The FADT table contains a mismatch between the 32 bit pointer (FIRMWARE_CTRL) and 64 bit pointer (X_FIRMWARE_CTRL) pointer to the FACS table.  Section 5.2.9 of version 4.0a of the ACPI specification states that X_FIRMWARE_CTRL should be zero if FIRMWARE_CTRL is defined, or FIRMWARE_CTRL should be zero if X_FIRMWARE_CTRL is zero. With two different pointers defined, the kernel has to make a choice, and opts for the 32 bit pointer. Because these pointers are different, it suggests either one of them is incorrect, or different 32 bit and 64 bit FACS tables are present in your system, which is NOT complaint with the ACPI specification.  The kernel has to make a choice and opts for the 32 bit FIRMWARE_CTRL.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Error.*32/64X address mismatch in.*, using 32
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: The FADT table contains a mismatch between a 32 bit pointer and a 64 bit Generic Address pointer. Because these pointers are different, it suggests either one of them is incorrect.  If a non-null 32 bit pointer exists, then the kernel will opt for this in preference to the 64 bit pointer even though this is not in accordance to the ACPI specification.
The FADT table contains Generic Address Structure that has a mismatch between the 32 bit and 64 bit versions of an address. This should be fixed so there are no mismatches.
A table contains Generic Address Structure that has a mismatch between the 32 bit and 64 bit versions of an address. This should be fixed so there are no mismatches.
ACPI AML interpreter executed a Method that returned a package with incorrectly typed data. The offending method needs to be fixed.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Warning.*Return Package has no elements
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: ACPI AML interpreter executed a Method that returned a package with no elements inside it. This is most probably a bug in the Method and needs to be fixed.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Warning.*Return Package is too small
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: ACPI AML interpreter executed a Method that returned a package with too few elements inside it. This is most probably a bug in the Method and needs to be fixed.
The ACPI table listed above has an incorrect checksum, this could be a BIOS bug or due to table corruption.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Warning.*_BQC returned an invalid level
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: Method _BQC (Brightness Query Current) returned an invalid display brightness level.
Method _BCL (Query List of Brightness Control Levels Supported) has a maximum brightness value which is not the last value in the returned package. Values returned must be in ascending order.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Error.*Too many duplicates in _BCL package
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: Method _BCL (Query List of Brightness Control Levels Supported) contains too many duplicated brightness levels in the returned package and this is non-standard.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Warning.*Could not enable fixed event

firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: The ACPI Method returned an incorrect type, this should be fixed.
The ACPI Method was executing with a different number of parameters than the Method expected. This should be fixed.
The ACPI Method has not enough arguments as expected. This should be fixed.
The ACPI Method returned a package with no elements in it, and some were exepected.This should be fixed.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Warning.*Converted Buffer to expected String
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: Method returned a Buffer type instead of a String type and ACPI driver automatically converted it to a String.  It is worth fixing this in the DSDT or SSDT even if the kernel fixes it at run time.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI Warning.*Return Package type mistmatch at index
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: The ACPI Method returned a package that contained data of the incorrect data type. This data type needs fixing.
This item in the FADT is the incorrect length. Should be corrected.

This is most probably caused by when a read or write operation to the EC memory has failed because of a timeout waiting for the Embedded Controller to complete the transaction.  Normally, the kernel waits for 500ms for the Embedded Controller status port to indicate that a transaction is complete, but in this case it has not and a AE_TIME error has been returned.
ACPI AML intepreter has found some non-conforming AML code. This should be investigated and fixed.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: ACPI.*BIOS bug: multiple APIC/MADT found, using
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: The kernel has detected more than one ACPI Multiple APIC Description Table (MADT) (these tables have the "APIC" signature). There should only be one MADT and the kernel will by default select the first one. However, one can override this and select the Nth MADT using acpi_apic_instance=N.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: \[Firmware Bug\]: ACPI.*Invalid physical address in GAR
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: ACPI Generic Address is invalid

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: \[Firmware Bug\]: powernow-k8.*(No PSB or ACPI _PSS objects|No compatible ACPI _PSS|Your BIOS does not provide ACPI _PSS objects)
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: The _PSS object (Performance Supported States) is an optional object that indicates the number of supported processor performance states. The powernow-k8 driver source states: If you see this message, complain to BIOS manufacturer. If he tells you "we do not support Linux" or some similar nonsense, remember that Windows 2000 uses the same legacy mechanism that the old Linux PSB driver uses. Tell them it is broken with Windows 2000. The reference to the AMD documentation is chapter 9 in the BIOS and Kernel Developer's Guide, which is available on www.amd.com.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: \[Firmware Bug\]: ACPI.*Invalid bit width in GAR
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: ACPI Generic Address width must be 8, 16, 32 or 64

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: \[Firmware Bug\]: ACPI.*Invalid address space type in GAR
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: ACPI Generic Address space type must be system memory or system IO space.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: \[Firmware Bug\]: ACPI.*no secondary bus range in _CRS
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: _CRS Method should return a secondary bus address for the status/command port. The kernel is having to guess this based on the _BBN or assume it's 0x00-0xff.
_PSS (Performance Supported States) package has an incorrectly define core frequency (first DWORD entry in the _PSS package).
_BQC (Brightness Query Current level) seems to be missing. This method returns the current brightness level of a built-in display output device.
_BQC (Brightness Query Current level) seems to be missing. This method returns the current brightness level of a built-in display output device.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: \[Firmware Bug\]: BIOS needs update for CPU frequency support
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: Having _PPC but missing frequencies (_PSS, _PCT) is a good hint that the BIOS is older than the CPU and does not know the CPU frequencies.

The Error Record Serialization Table (ERST) seems to be invalid. This normally indicates that the ERST table header size is too small, or the table size (excluding header) is not a multiple of the ERST entries.
ACPI _CRT (Critical Trip Point) is returning a threshold lower than zero degrees Celsius which is clearly incorrect.
No valud ACPI _CRT (Critical Trip Point) was found.
ACPI Method _BCQ was defined (typo) instead of _BQC - this should be fixed.however the kernel has detected this and is working around this typo.
The MultiProcessor table has an incorrect signature, it should be PCMP. The kernel cannot trust the table and has disabled SMP support.
The MultiProcessor table has an incorrect checksum. The kernel cannot trust the table and has disabled SMP support.
The MultiProcessor table has an incorrect version. It should be 0x01 or 0x04 (for versions 1.1 and 1.4 respectively). The kernel cannot trust the table and has disabled SMP support.
The MultiProcessor table contains a NULL Local APIC address but the Local APIC address must be defined. The kernel has disabled SMP support.
The MultiProcessor table contains no Processor Entry Fields, and hence there are no CPUs defined. The kernel has no option but to disable SMP support.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: BIOS bug.*no explicit IRQ entries.*using default mptable
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: The MultiProcessor table contains no IRQ Entry Fields, and hence there are no IRQs defined. The table is broken and should be fixed. The kernel will set up the low 16 IO-APIC pins to the ISA defaults in the hope the machine may work.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: BIOS bug.*timer not connected to IO-APIC
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: The BIOS is reporting the ExtINTA I/O APIC input from the cascaded 8259A as the timer interrupt input.  The kernel has detected just one pin, so it has to check the timer directly and through the 8259A because of the broken BIOS reporting.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: BIOS bug,.*IO-APIC.*ID is.*in the MPC table.*
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: The IO-APIC id in the MPC table is wrong and the kernel has detected this and attempted to fix it. The MPC table in the firmware needs to be fixed.

The IO-APIC id has been defined more than once in the MPC table, which is a firmware bug and should be fixed. The kernel has detected this and skopped this duplication to avoid stuck on smp_invalidate_needed IPI wait' messages.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: WARNING.*BIOS bug.*CPU MTRRs don't cover all of memory, losing
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: The Memory Type Range Registers (MTRRs) which define memory caching policy are misconfigued by the BIOS and don't appear to cover all available physical memory. The kernel has detected this and has reduced the amount of memory available to be safe. Either check that the BIOS memory caching options are set correctly or contact your BIOS vendor to get this fixed.

ACPI Method _DOD (Enumerate all devices attached to display adapter) is defined but we should also have _DOS (Enable/Disable output switching) defined but it's been omitted. This can cause display switching issues.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: WARNING:.*bogus zero IO-APIC address found in MPTABLE
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: An IO-APIC address of zero has been found in the MPTABLE and is thus treated as misconfigured or bogus. I/O APIC support has been disabled. This is considered a firmware bug and the MPTABLE needs to be fixed.

An IO-APIC address of zero has been found in the MPTABLE and is thus treated as misconfigured or bogus. I/O APIC support has been disabled. This is considered a firmware bug and the MPTABLE needs to be fixed.
Try video module parameter video.allow_duplicates=1 if the current driver does't work.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: \[Firmware Bug\]:.*PCI.*MMCONFIG.*not reserved in ACPI motherboard resources
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: It appears that PCI config space has been configured for a specific device but does not appear to be reserved by the ACPI motherboard resources.

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: \[Firmware Bug\]: PCI.*not reserved in ACPI motherboard resources
firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: PCI firmware bug. Please see the kernel log for more details.

This is not exactly a failure mode but a warning from the kernel. The _OSI() method has implemented a match to the 'Linux' query in the DSDT and this is redundant because the ACPI driver matches onto the Windows _OSI strings by default.
ACPI driver has detected an ACPI bug. This generally points to a bug in an ACPI table. Examine the kernel log for more details.
The kernel has detected a Firmware bug in the BIOS or ACPI which needs investigating and fixing.
The kernel has detected an error trying to execute an Method and it cannot find an object. This is indicates a bug in the DSDT or SSDT AML code.
The ACPI engine has failed to execute some AML. The error message above lists the method that caused this error.
The kernel has most probably detected an error while executing ACPI AML. The error lists the ACPI driver module and the line number where the bug has been caught and the method that caused the error.
Execution of an ACPI AML method failed.
ACPI method reached maximum reentrancy limit of 255 - infinite recursion in AML in DSTD or SSDT

firmware_error_warning_patterns.pattern: \*\*\* Error.*Method reached maximum reentrancy limitACPI method has reached reentrancy limit, this is a recursion bug in the AML

firmware_error_warning_patterns.advice: Return object type is not the correct type, this is an AML error in the DSDT or SSDT

pm_error_warning_patterns.advice: dpm_prepare() failed to prepare all non-sys devices for a system PM transition. The device should be listed in the error message.

pm_error_warning_patterns.pattern: PM: Some devices failed to power down
pm_error_warning_patterns.advice: dpm_suspend_noirq failed because some devices did not power down

pm_error_warning_patterns.pattern: PM: Some system devices failed to power down
pm_error_warning_patterns.advice: sysdev_suspend failed because some system devices did not power down.

pm_error_warning_patterns.pattern: PM: Some devices failed to power down

pm_error_warning_patterns.advice: A resume from hibernate failed when calling hibernation_restore()
There was not enough physical memory to be able to generate a hibernation image before dumping it to disc.
swusp_alloc() failed trying to allocate highmem and failing that non-highmem pages for the suspend image. There is probably just not enough free physcial memory available.
Mismatch in kernel version, system type, kernel release version or machine id between suspended kernel and resumed kernel.

pm_error_warning_patterns.pattern: PM: Some devices failed to power down
PM: Some devices failed to suspend
PM: no wakealarm-capable RTC driver is ready
PM: Adding page to bio failed at
pm_error_warning_patterns.advice: An attempt to write the hibernate image to disk failed because a write BIO operation failed. This is usually a result of some physical hardware problem.
An attempt to write a hibernate image to disk failed because a valid swap device header could not be found. Make sure there is a formatted swap device on the machine and it is added using swapon -a.
An attempt to write a hibernate image to disk failed because the swap device could not be found. Make sure there is a formatted swap device on the machine and it is added using swapon -a.
Hibernate failed because the swap parition was probably too small.
The BIOS seems to be corrupting the first 64K of memory when doing suspend/resume. Setting bios_corruption_check=0 will disable this check.

Possibly an Intel I/O controller hub HPET Write Timing issue: A read transaction that immediately follows a write transaction to the HPET TIMn_COMP Timer 0 (108h), HPET MAIN_CNT (0F0h), or TIMn_CONF.bit 6 (100h) may return an incorrect value.  This is known to cause issues when coming out of S3.
Softlock errors that occur when coming out of S3 may be tripped by TSC warping.  It may be worth trying the notsc kernel parameter and repeating S3 tests to see if this solves the problem.
